title: express.logger throws error
Error starting express app
body: `node app` does not work, `node ./bin/www` is how I have to start the app

title: Some of the express examples are failing
Express generates wrong less-middleware code
body:
Hi, I found a problem when I run the Express command with the --css less option, in the app.js:

```
app.use(require('less-middleware')({ src: path.join(__dirname, 'public') }));
```

It should be:

```
app.use(require('less-middleware')(path.join(__dirname, 'public'), {options}));
```

Because the middleware take the first parameter as the source, and the second as the object with the options. I know because I got an error with path.js, and it was because the source wasn't a string.

title: Express suddenly starts to tell me things like express.favicon() are error. Where is the migration guide?
body: Would be nice to provide a migration guide from 3.x to 4.x.

title: deprecate app.render (make private)
body: First step in isolating the view system away from "app" level and towards something that can be used via middleware later.

title: Fixed deprecated example doctype
res.send(statusCode) and res.json(statusCode) have different behavior
body:
i'm not sure if this is intentional or not, but it seems odd to me that `res.json(400)` and `res.send(400)` have different behavior. res.send(400) sends a response with an empty body and a status of 400, as described in the documentation, but res.json(400) send a response with string literal "400" and a status of 200.

it seems intuitive to me for them to work the same way. if you want to send the string "400" then you could just call `res.send('400')`.

title: redirect can take a hash of queries
body: I found that it would often be helpful to pass information to another page via a query string, so I added the ability to include an object of `{ q : val, q2 : val2 }` as either the second or third variable (in the case of having codes or not). The parsing of redirect string and code values (order not mattering) should be preserved.

title: __express template engine hook removal
body:
From this page:
https://github.com/visionmedia/express/wiki/4.x-roadmap

@visionmedia seems that at one point you were thinking about removing the automatic `__express` hook detection and requiring manual adding.

I am also exploring the view breaking API change of having settings and locals no longer smashed into the same object (tho I think I can do this without breaking old api by just adding a new param to the renderFile function).

Do you or @jonathanong have thoughts on removing this auto __express detection and requiring that the user always explicitly map engines (+1 from me).

title: make express.Router() return a Router function instance
body:
Similar to how express() returns an express `app` instance which is also
a function, express.Router() returns the Router instance which is also a
function and can be easily used via another router or the app.

app.use(express.Router());

title: Router: add parameter handling to middleware
body:
Middleware (.use) can now specify parameter arguments to trigger
Router.param loading. This is handy if you want to `.use` additional
routers but need to load certain objects before the mounted middleware
runs.

This will resolve #696

title: req.body is empty when sending HTTP status code via app.all()
body:
- Do a POST, submitting whatever data
- handle it via app.all(), respond with a status

```
app.all('*',function(req,res,next){
  console.dir(req.body);
  res.send(403);
});
```

console will log an empty object

---
- Do a POST, submitting whatever data
- handle it via app.all(), respond with a message 

```
app.all('*',function(req,res,next){
  console.dir(req.body);
  res.send('Foobar');
});
```

console will log the POST data

title: Remove connect
body:
Remove the last dependence on connect!!

Most of this PR is updated examples. But some things of note are listed below:
- no middleware is bundled by default except `static` which is really a thin wrapper around `send`
- `patch.js` from connect is copied over into this repo until we decide how to best deal with it (or if we even need it)

title: move `.query` to the `request` prototype
body:
https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/application.js#L102

we could also just remove it. what do you guys think? i think a `qs` middleware would be pretty useless by itself.

title: Bundled middleware for express 4
body:
Express 4 will no longer depend on connect and thus none of the middleware will be there. It would be kinda annoying to have nothing available by default so this issue is to discuss what to include.

I propose:

Favicon
Static
CookieParser
Logger (Morgan)

However I am also happy leaning towards bundling even less or nothing!

title: Set Content-Type on static files
body:
Using a simple server script using express to serve static files, I find that the resulting server is not setting the Content-Type header.  This causes problems in some browsers that strictly follow the rules.

A workaround would be to write more complex code that specifically reads each file and sets the Content-Type manually, but I would think this would be a clear responsibility of the server out of the box.

title: Allow app#set to accept a hash of settings
body: This would, among other things, allow simpler integration with configuration modules like [rc](https://github.com/dominictarr/rc).

body:
Hi all,

I am using sailjs which depending express@3.4.7. In root sailsjs folder, I used "npm install". All packages were installed pretty well, except express :| which depending cookie@0.1.0. 

When I ran server with "grunt server", it fired the error 
"Fatal error: Cannot find module 'express/node_modules/cookie'"

I didn't find cookie module in express/node_modules. 

I found that the reason was I just added cookie@0.1.0 in root package.json which I used it for testing sailsjs API. 

So, how can I keep depending cookie@0.1.0 in sailsjs package.json and express/node_modules?

Thanks for helping!
Henry

Not sure what express can do here, but this makes it very hard to consume it on windows at least.

flash socket policy problem
body:
Hi,
I have small application on nodejs + expressjs + socket.io and it works like a charm... mostly.

There is problem with flash [socket policy server](http://www.adobe.com/devnet/flashplayer/articles/socket_policy_files.html). Thing is that I cannot run socket policy server on port 843. If Flash Player cannot retrieve a master policy file from port 843, then it requests a socket policy file on the port where it is trying to connect. So the solution could be on 80 respond to normal http request (with express) and on the same port catch plain TCP connection with data '<policy-file-request/>\0' and respond with policy. I was trying adapt [this code](https://gist.github.com/mattcg/489841) but without luck.

Any one can help me with that?

yo what's an empty string in JS? let's say you got cross-platform, you rock objective-c or otherwise close to c hopefully (#controlflowrhymes). tendencies for allocation via pointerisms and voidisms reveal truth where javascript finds false:

title: *.svgz files not supported?
body:
I'm not sure, but when I use *.svgz (compressed svg files) I get the following error:

```
This page contains the following errors:
error on line 1 at column 1: Encoding error
Below is a rendering of the page up to the first error.
```

*.svg files work.

On Apache I must add the following line in the .htaccess file to work with .svgz files:

```
AddType image/svg+xml      svg svgz
AddEncoding gzip               svgz
```

Is there a similar function in express or support express it principle not?

title: fibrous.middleware and setHeader error
remove app.router and refactor middleware processing
body:
This is an overhaul of middleware processing, Router and Route. Connect is no
longer used to process the middleware stack. This functionality has been
split into two parts: middleware stack and default error response.

The entry point for request processing is the `app.handle` method. It
sets up the default error response handle (to run in the event of no
other error handler) and then triggers the app router (instance of
Router) to handle the request.

The app router `handle` function contains the middleware dispatch layer
previously in the connect codebase. This layer handle the logic for
dispatching `.use` calls (stripping paths if needed). The app contains a
base router `app._router`. New routes can be created and `.use`d on this
router to organize routes into files.

Routers now have the following methods `.use`, `.all`, `.param` which
are all public.

Additionally, Routers have a `.route(path)` method which returns a new
instance of Route for the requested path. Route(s) are isolated
middleware stacks and contain methods for the HTTP verbs as well as an
`.all` method to act similar to middleware. These methods are chainable
to easily describe requirements for a route.

  var route = Router.route('/foo'); // or 'app.route('/foo')'

  route
  .all(auth)
  .get(function(...) {})
  .all(more_checks)
  .post(function(...) {})

Any Route and Router methods which accept handlers also accept error
(arity 4) handlers which will also behave as expected.

Finally, the `app.router` getter has been removed. Middleware and
handlers are run IN THE ORDER they are seen in the file. This means that
code which injected the `app.router` and then added error handlers (or
other middleware) will need to be updated to move those handlers after
any requests added on the app object. The examples have been updated
accordingly. This is the largest breaking change to codebases in this
commit.

title: res.sendfile does not accept file system paths
Make each route a separate middleware stack.
body:
DO NOT MERGE THIS

This PR is only for code review and API change review and discussion.

This is the start of a number of larger changes that I hope to land for the 4.0 release. All of the changes will be surrounding routing. This particular changeset changes what a `Route` is. Previously, a Route would be defined by the path, method, and callbacks. Now a Route is only a path. This route can have middleware applied to it via (.use) and has all of the http verbs (.get, .post) etc. This makes all routes self contained middleware stacks. It also changes the behavior of the `Router.route` method call. Previously this took a method, path, and callbacks. Now it just takes a path and returns the created `Route` object allowing for the following API style:

``` js
router.route('/foobar')
.use(fn...)
.use(fn...)
.get(fn..)
.post(fn...)
```

This likewise means that once I remove the `app.route` property from its currently hacky use for mounted apps, we will also be able to do the same on the `app` variables.

``` js
app.route('/user')
.use()
.get()
.post()
```

Taking this one step further, I want to remove the dependency on connect as mentioned by @jonathanong so that we can have control over our routing stack allowing us to possibly throw on out of order app.use calls or somehow be smarter about it (not relevant to this current changeset).

A side effect of these changes (I did not intend for this) is that the benchmarks run faster (on my computer). This may have to do with the particular way the benchmark suite is setting up middleware or routes that just lends itself more favorably to this new route approach.

No tests have been adding for the new API as I am looking for general feelings on this change and landing the above described changes for 4.0.

title: Middleware API incomplete
body:
The list of available Middleware methods -- see http://expressjs.com/api.html#middleware -- is incomplete. The code in the page looks as if it should have several more methods, but the include is not being performed: ``` [...snip...]

directory()

Directory serving middleware, serves the given path. This middleware may be paired with static() to serve files, providing a full-featured file browser. 

app.use(express.directory('public'))
app.use(express.static('public'))

This middleware accepts the following options:

  • hidden display hidden (dot) files. Defaults to false.
  • icons display icons. Defaults to false.
  • filter Apply this filter function to files. Defaults to false.
```

title: Can't parse post bodies
Remove app.configure
body:
We have long wanted to remove this code since any sort of configure logic is trivial to do at the app level. It also minimizes our use of magic env variables.

Besides the removal of app.configure, the other breaking change is `json spaces` off by default. If users want to pretty print json, there are plenty of awesome browser extensions or they can enable it in their app however they want.

I wish the view cache setting was also something we could stop using the env var for by default but that is a more serious breaking change. Maybe given that this is all for a 4.x target we could document it and require folks to set it themselves (which I believe to be the correct course of action).

title: jump support added to next() middleware calling technique
body:
next(null, 1) will skip next 1st handler and jump to 2nd handler in middleware

and next(null, -1) will invoke last handler in middleware
next(null, -2) will invoke 2nd last handler and so on.

title: jump support added to next() middleware calling technique
body:
next(1) will skip next 1st handler and jump to 2nd handler in middleware

and next(-1) will invoke last handler in middleware

title: not working jade

title: Express does not return HTTP 405 when the method is not allowed.
body:
This issue is similar to #1499, but that was closed with the implementation apparently only partially fixed.

When a URL is not handled at all, then 404 is the correct status, because Express does not know of a resource at that URL.

However when a URL is handled, but with a different method (i.e. has a GET handler, but not a POST handler), then Express does know of a resource at this location, but does not know how to handle this particular method. In this case, a 405 is the correct status code.

The previous issue was closed with a comment saying it is a matter of opinion, but I don't think it is, I think Express is currently not following the specification correctly, and it's currently up to developers to add code to conform properly. I think it is reasonable for developers to expect and assume that their framework will do this for them.

Support for this was added to 'express-subroute', but as this is an incorrect handling of the HTTP spec, the functionality for returning 405s should really be in Express core, and not rely on developers finding a separate package, and adding extra functionality with it that they don't need.

text/html is sending without a charset.
body:
Compare the headers on a page served via `render` (sendFile does the same thing) [[1]](https://searchbeam.jit.su/)

With one statically served from connect's static server [[2]](https://searchbeam.jit.su/s/test.html)

Express is serving pages that don't have a charset for some reason.
([Which is discouraged](http://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-html-encoding-declarations))

The `send` module is not the issue. As far as I can tell express is setting the `content-type` somewhere and forgetting header charsets for html.

title: res.sendfile() rejects/mangles some valid file system paths
body:
Express/Send has a problem in `res.sendfile` if the path has characters which would be escaped in a URL. In some cases it will reject the path as invalid, and in some cases it will actually mangle the path. This seems to be because it is calling `decodeURIComponent` on the path.

https://github.com/visionmedia/send/blob/master/lib/send.js#L297

Some examples of paths that are rejected/mangled:

```
express rejects path: /Users/jeff/Pictures/iPhoto Library/Thumbnails/2012/10/06/20121006-103601/yI%6UxAgRnOnHWH6659V0Q/P9225012.jpg
express rejects path: /Users/jeff/Pictures/iPhoto Library/Thumbnails/2012/10/06/20121006-103601/jMQ%putSQKm58erJTWmn+g/P9225014.jpg
express mangles path: /Users/jeff/Pictures/iPhoto Library/Thumbnails/2012/10/06/20121006-103601/Eo%64jpVT36booQOByN2MA/P9225017.jpg
```

Even though the underlying issue appears to be in Send, I chose to file the issue in Express since (a) it is more user-facing, and (b) I'm not sure what the 'fix' is and therefore not really sure where the fix should be made.

Cheers!

title: Why is the value in app.set required to be a String?
body:
My IDE told me today that I was using `app.set()` incorrectly, because I was providing Objects for the value of the setting.

This was working well for me so far, but https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/application.js#L245 indicates that this is not intended.

So, what's the reason for this?

title: Javascript objects in express  functions
Suggestion:  Session middleware should default to respecting the "trust proxy" setting
body:
Just a suggestion, but it might be convenient for developers if the Connect session middleware exposed through Express were wrapped in order to use the `"trust proxy"` setting as the default value for the `proxy` option.  It seems like the cases where `"trust proxy"` and the `proxy` option would be different are small and the need to specify the option in both places is likely to catch developers off-guard if they aren't reading the documentation closely (this may have been behind #967 and just surprised me a bit).

If not the default, a note in the documentation to remind developers they need to specify the option in both places in order to use a proxy could be helpful.

Thanks for considering,
Kevin

title: Please help
body:
I am using express behind enterprise corporate proxy/firewall. 
I am struggling because because I just don't know where to set proxy for node.js

I usually export http_proxy="http://<username>:<password>@myproxy.com:8080 at prompt. This is just sufficient. 

But this setting is not working for node.js. 
Please help.
Should I use node-http-proxy if yes then please give a simple code sample for my code request. 
Else just give a sample express/node.js to do this. 

Thanks in advance.

title: Unable to change max-age HTTP header
mounting sub apps with a route prefix doesn't support :params
doctype 5 is deprecated, use doctype html
body:
I used the express shell command to generate a new project. Then I tried to start up that project.

It has an error that says 'doctype 5' is deprecated. I updated the jade layout file to 'doctype html' and it works. But probably it shouldnt be generated like this.

Thank you

title: `bodyParser` in examples
body:
There are some examples (auth, cookies, cors, multipart, mvc, route-separation) that are using `bodyParser` which causes `connect.multipart` warning.

I'd be happy to submit a pull request, but I found there are no tests for them. Given this, I'd prefer to write the needed tests first, add package.json files etc. and then take care of the warnings. I think what you guys did with koajs/examples is great and express could take this path too.

In case this makes sense to you, let me know, I'd be happy to take care of it.

title: Website API Reference page Middleware list appears truncated
body: When expanded, the website API Reference page Middleware list appears truncated as it only lists middleware beginning with letters b, c, or d. Means a lot of documentation is missing.

title: update express jade layout generator
body: update doctype

title: Updated the example file to use `doctype html` on  because  `doctype 5` was deprecated on Jade version 1.0.0.
Changed `doctype 5` to `doctype html' because the former was deprecated on Jade version 1.0.0.
`doctype 5` is deprecated
body:
`doctype 5` is deprecated, it should use `doctype html`.

And follow the steps to build a express project with jade, after `node app`, It jumps an error telling change to `doctype html`

title: fix error 'doctype 5 is deprecated' in index
body: 'layout.jade' obsolete after start new express project. Fix using 'doctype html' instead of 'doctype 5'

title: my express
body: aa

title: `body.length` in docs should be `Buffer.byteLength(body, 'utf-8')`?
Error message now describes where the view was not able to be found.
body: This is an issue that sometimes arises when a view cannot be found and there is insufficient information to ascertain why. This patch adds the views directory that was tried to the error message returned when a view could not be found.

title: Automatic OPTIONS response breaks with multiple routers
body:
We ran into a situation where a middleware from a node module was creating its own express router instance and inserting it as middleware. This was causing the automatic options to break since the flow never fell back to our main router. I don't know what your views on supporting applications that use multiple routers are.

It would be very easy to fix by passing `next` to `_options`, and then calling it if the response from `_optionsFor` is empty. This would also have the added benefit of returning 404 errors for `OPTIONS` requests to routes that don't exist, which I believe is standard practice.

However, the downside of this is that if you have multiple verbs for a single route spread over two routers, it won't return all the available verbs. So it may not be a complete fix, depending on how you view it. If you like the fix, I can submit a pull request (though it is only 4 lines).

title: Different rendering behavior for objects when explicit content type is set

body: Failed at the jade@0.35.0 prepublish script.

title: app.set('views', <this dir is relative to where node is run>)
body: Since every other path is relative to the file in which is referenced, is there a specific reason that the path used in `app.set('views'` is relative to the path that `node` is called in? If anything, it may be good to put into docs because of the unexpected behavior (at least unexpected for me... it took me longer than I'd like to admit to figure this out)

body:
When running the node.js HTTPS module using express the `req.protocol` is reporting `http` when it should be reporting `https`

Environment information:
Host: `Ubuntu Linux jas-laptop 3.2.0-57-generic #87-Ubuntu SMP Tue Nov 12 21:35:10 UTC 2013 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`

VM s/w: `QEMU emulator version 1.0 (qemu-kvm-1.0), Copyright (c) 2003-2008 Fabrice Bellard`

VM Guest: `CentOS Linux node.dev 2.6.32-431.1.2.0.1.el6.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Dec 13 13:06:13 UTC 2013 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`

Relevant source; [app.js](https://github.com/jas-/node-dhcp-manager/blob/master/libs/app.js) & [server.js](https://github.com/jas-/node-dhcp-manager/blob/master/libs/server.js).

I verified that the connection between the host & guest are indeed using SSL with the following `tcpdump` commands:

Guest: `tcpdump -ieth0 -s 1024 -l -A tcp port 3000`
Results: `E..^I...@...

10:38:38.444436 IP jas-laptop.3000 > localhost.59080: Flags [P.], seq 2488:2780, ack 5311, win 256, options [nop,nop,TS val 1898456 ecr 1898455], length 292`

any diff between `http.createServer(app).listen(..)` and `app.listen(..)`?
body: Thanks!!

title: CookieParser vs req.cookies
body:
When I read about [req.cookies](http://expressjs.com/api.html#req.cookies) in expressjs docs, it says

> When the cookieParser() middleware is used this object defaults to {}, otherwise contains the cookies sent by the user-agent.

And when I read about [CookieParser middleware](http://expressjs.com/api.html#cookieParser), it says

> Parses the Cookie header field and populates req.cookies with an object keyed by the cookie names.

So, `req.cookies` says if I use CookieParser, it will be set to `{}`, but CookieParser says it will populate `req.cookies`. Sounds confusing to me.

My question is, why do we need CookieParser, if req.cookies itself gives the cookies? I asked [this question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20550656/cookieparser-vs-req-cookies-expressjs) in stackoverflow also.

title: Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor called on inherited property causes unhalted TypeError
body:
`connect.middleware` object seems to have 'isString' function in its prototype chain which makes Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor() to fail. I experienced that after running express 3.4.6 with connect 2.11.2. 

```
c:\Users\xxx\express\lib\express.js:48
  Object.defineProperty(
         ^
TypeError: Property description must be an object: undefined
    at Function.defineProperty (native)
    at Object.<anonymous> (c:\Users\xxx\express\lib\express.js:48:10)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:364:17)
    at require (module.js:380:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (c:\Users\xxx\express\index.js:4:5)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
```

Besides from the above-mentioned circumstance I think it would be reasonable in general to filter object properties before calling something like `Object.get ===> Own <=== PropertyDescriptor()` on them.

title: run a script at object creation
body:
hi,

for this example:
- table userr:
  - column name
  - column token

I need to generate a token each time I create a new object in express. I thought about running a script to do it. But how can I implement it and called it.

To have something like this:

  - column name: (add by hand)
  - column token: (generated from a script)

Thx

title: Regexp route working 50% of the time
body:
I do not really know if it's a bug or if I am really stupid, but this problem have been driving me nuts.

I have a really simple route usign regular expression. If I hit the same path a second time, it fails to route and responds with a 404.

Basicaly, my path is:

``` js
app.get(/\/c\/(https?:\/\/.+)/gi, routes.create);
```

And I use this path: `/c/http://28hu.it` 

The route is defined here https://github.com/DeuxHuitHuit/28hu.it/blob/master/server.js#L55

I had this problem with 3.0.6, but the upgrade to 3.4.6 had the same behavior.
